traffic_visible_response: 正在搜索找到 3 篇资料参考The term "black jails" refers to illegal detention facilities that operate outside the legal framework. Here is a detailed introduction:### Basic Definition- **Nature**: Black jails are institutions where individuals are detained by the state without access to legal process or representation. They have no official or legal status and are not part of the formal detention or imprisonment system.### Existence Background- **Replacement for the abolished system**: In China, after the custody and repatriation system was abolished in 2003 due to the Sun Zhigang incident, black jails emerged as a substitute.- **Response to the petitioning system**: They are mainly used to detain petitioners who go to higher - level governments to seek redress for grievances that have not been resolved at the local level. With the increase in the number of people using the petitioning system since 1993, the authorities have adopted this illegal way to deal with petitioners.### Detention Locations- **Diverse settings**: These facilities can be found in state - owned hotels, hostels, hospitals, psychiatric facilities, residential buildings, or government ministry buildings.### Treatment of Detainees- **Human rights violations**: Detainees are often physically and psychologically abused, including being beaten, starved, and hosed down with water. They may also be deprived of food, sleep, and medical care. In addition, detainees have no access to family members, legal counsel, or the courts. There have even been cases of guards raping female petitioners.### Official Stance- **Denial of existence**: The Chinese government has repeatedly denied the existence of black jails. For example, at a press briefing of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in April 2009, an official denied the existence of black jails in response to a question from an Al Jazeera correspondent.
